channel.title: NPR Programs: All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Why the longest shutdown in American history still isn't over
item.description: The Senate holds a rare Sunday session but remains deadlocked over health care tax credits and shows no clear path to reopening the government. The president weighs in on social media.
item.content:encoded: The Senate holds a rare Sunday session but remains deadlocked over health care tax credits and shows no clear path to reopening the government. The president weighs in on social media.
item.dc:creator: Luke Garrett

item.title: The fragile truce in Gaza edges toward its next phase
item.description: Hamas says it has returned remains of an Israeli soldier held in Gaza since 2014. It's a sign of progress towards the next stage of the ceasefire. Meanwhile, President Trump's envoy and son-in-law, Jared Kushner, returns to Israel.
item.content:encoded: Hamas says it has returned remains of an Israeli soldier held in Gaza since 2014. It's a sign of progress towards the next stage of the ceasefire. Meanwhile, President Trump's envoy and son-in-law, Jared Kushner, returns to Israel.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Frayer

item.title: What's behind your phone cravings and how movement can replace them
item.description: Breaking your scrolling habit could help you feel calmer, happier, and more energized. NPR's Life Kit explains how to get there.
item.content:encoded: Breaking your scrolling habit could help you feel calmer, happier, and more energized. NPR's Life Kit explains how to get there.
item.dc:creator: Marielle Segarra

item.title: How movies turn heartbreak into comedy, tragedy, and everything in between
item.description: From revenge plots to quiet goodbyes, breakup movies explore how people rebuild when love falls apart.
item.content:encoded: From revenge plots to quiet goodbyes, breakup movies explore how people rebuild when love falls apart.
item.dc:creator: Sacha Pfeiffer

item.title: What the push for affordability reveals about wealth inequality
item.description: Columbia University professor and Nobel Prize laureate Joseph Stiglitz warns that unchecked inequality is pushing America toward economic and political peril.
item.content:encoded: Columbia University professor and Nobel Prize laureate Joseph Stiglitz warns that unchecked inequality is pushing America toward economic and political peril.
item.dc:creator: Ahmad Damen

item.title: 'I Love LA' finds humor in the chaos of trying to make it in Hollywood
item.description: Comedian Rachel Sennott turns her chaotic twenties in Los Angeles into the HBO series 'I Love LA', a comedy about friendship, identity, and growing up online.
item.content:encoded: Comedian Rachel Sennott turns her chaotic twenties in Los Angeles into the HBO series 'I Love LA', a comedy about friendship, identity, and growing up online.
item.dc:creator: Kira Wakeam

item.title: Brazil's favela residents are demanding a say in climate talks
item.description: As Brazil prepares to host COP30, residents of Rio de Janeiro's favelas are mobilizing to make sure the voices of the world's informal settlements aren't left out of global climate talks.
item.content:encoded: As Brazil prepares to host COP30, residents of Rio de Janeiro's favelas are mobilizing to make sure the voices of the world's informal settlements aren't left out of global climate talks.
item.dc:creator: JÃºlia Dias Carneiro

item.title: The first novel from Craig Thomas, co-creator of 'How I Met Your Mother,' parallels his life
item.description: The novel blends sharp satire of Hollywood with a deeply personal look at family, marriage, and raising a child with disabilities.
item.content:encoded: The novel blends sharp satire of Hollywood with a deeply personal look at family, marriage, and raising a child with disabilities.
item.dc:creator: Sacha Pfeiffer

item.title: In upstate New York, the shutdown means hunger and hard choices
item.description: From Saranac Lake, Emily Russell of North Country Public Radio reports on how families are scrambling to get by as vital aid programs remain frozen.
item.content:encoded: From Saranac Lake, Emily Russell of North Country Public Radio reports on how families are scrambling to get by as vital aid programs remain frozen.
item.dc:creator: Emily Russell

item.title: As the shutdown drags on, Senator Klobuchar urges action
item.description: Sen. Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota says Democrats are united on affordability and calls on the president to help end the shutdown.
item.content:encoded: Sen. Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota says Democrats are united on affordability and calls on the president to help end the shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Avery Keatley
